Package meka.core

Class StatUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • meka.core.StatUtils

  • public abstract class StatUtils
extends Object
    StatUtils - Helpful statistical functions.
    Version:
    March 2013 - Multi-target Compatible
    Author:
    Jesse Read (jesse@tsc.uc3m.es)

        P - Empirical prior.
        Parameters:
        Y - label matrix
        x - label values
        Returns:
        [P(Y_1==x[1]), P(Y_2==x[2]), ..., P(Y_L==x[L])]

                         int[] j,
                         int[] x)
        P - Empirical prior.
        Parameters:
        Y - label matrix
        x - label values
        j - label indices
        Returns:
        [P(Y_j[1]==x[1]), P(Y_j[2]==x[2]), ..., P(Y_j[L]==x[L])]

                       int j,
                       int k)

        Parameters:
        Y - label matrix
        j - label index
        k - label value
        Returns:
        P(Y_j==k) in Y.

        Parameters:

        j_ - label value
        Returns:

      • P

        public static double P​(double[][] Y,
                       int j,
                       int v,
                       int k,
                       int w)
        P - Empirical joint. Multi-target friendly.
        Parameters:
        Y - label matrix
        j - 1st label index
        v - 1st label value
        k - 2nd label index
        w - 2nd label value
        Returns:
        P(Y_j = v, Y_k = w) in Y.

      • P

        public static double P​(weka.core.Instances D,
                       int j,
                       int v,
                       int k,
                       int w)
        p - Empirical joint. Multi-target friendly.
        Parameters:
        D - Instances
        j - 1st label index
        v - 1st label value
        k - 2nd label index
        w - 2nd label value
        Returns:
        P(Y_j = v, Y_k = w) in D.

      • P

        public static double P​(weka.core.Instances D,
                       int[] j,
                       int[] v)
        P - Empirical joint. Multi-target friendly.
        Parameters:
        D - Instances
        j - label indices, e.g., 1,2,3
        v - label values, e.g., 0,0,1
        Returns:
        P(x_1,x_2,x_3 = v_1,v_2,v_3) for j = 1,2,3 in D

        Returns:

                                int k,
                                int l)
        Joint Distribution.
        Returns:
        the joint PMF of the j-th and k-th and lthlabels in D.

      • getP

        public static double[][] getP​(weka.core.Instances D)
        GetP - Get a pairwise empirical joint-probability matrix P[][] from dataset D.
        NOTE multi-label only

      • getApproxC

        public static int[][] getApproxC​(weka.core.Instances D)
        GetApproxP - A fast version of getC(D), based on frequent sets. Actually, if we don't prune, this is not even approximate -- it is the real empirical P.

      • getApproxP

        public static double[][] getApproxP​(weka.core.Instances D)
        GetApproxP - A fast version of getP(D), based on frequent sets. Actually, if we don't prune, this is not even approximate -- it is the real empirical P.

      • getP

        public static double[][] getP​(int[][] C,
                              int N)

      • getC

        public static int[][] getC​(weka.core.Instances D)
        GetC - Get pairwise co-ocurrence counts from the training data D.
        NOTE multi-label only
        Returns:
        C[][] where C[j][k] is the number of times where Y[i][j] = 1 and y[i][k] = 1 over all i = 1,...,N

      • I

        public static double I​(int[][] C,
                       int j,
                       int k,
                       int Ncount)
        I - Mutual Information I(y_j;y_k). multi-label only -- count version
        Parameters:
        C - count matrix
        j - j-th label index
        k - k-th label index
        Ncount - number of instances in the training set
        Returns:
        H(Y_j|Y_k)

      • H

        public static double H​(int[][] C,
                       int j,
                       int k,
                       int Ncount)
        H - Conditional Entropy H(y_j|y_k). multi-label only
        Parameters:
        C - count matrix
        j - j-th label index
        k - k-th label index
        Ncount - number of instances in the training set
        Returns:
        H(Y_j|Y_k)

        public static double[][] I​(double[][] P)
        I - Mutual Information -- fast version, must calcualte P[][] = getP(D) first.
        Returns:
        I[][]
        See Also:
        I(double[][], int, int)

      • I

        public static double I​(double[][] P,
                       int j,
                       int k)
        I - Mutual Information.
        NOTE binary only
        Returns:
        I(Y_j;Y_k) in dataset D.

      • I

        public static double I​(weka.core.Instances D,
                       int j,
                       int k)
        I - Mutual Information.
        NOTE Multi-target friendly (does not assume binary labels).
        NOTE a bit slow
        Returns:
        I(Y_j;Y_k) in dataset D.

      • I

        public static double[][] I​(weka.core.Instances D,
                           int L)
        I - Get an Unconditional Depndency Matrix. (Works for both ML and MT data).
        Parameters:
        D - dataset
        L - number of labels
        Returns:
        a L*L matrix representing Unconditional Depndence.

      • chi2

        public static double chi2​(weka.core.Instances Y,
                          int j,
                          int k)
        Chi^2 - Do the chi-squared test on the j-th and k-th labels in Y.
        NOTE multi-label only! @TODO Use enumerateValues() !!!
        If they are correlated, this means unconditional dependence!
        Returns:
        The chi-square statistic for labels j and k in Y.

      • chi2

        public static double[][] chi2​(weka.core.Instances D)
        Chi^2 - Do the chi-squared test on all pairs of labels.
        Parameters:
        D - dataset
        Returns:
        The chi-square statistic matrix X
        See Also:
        chi2(Instances, int, int)

      • chi2

        public static double[][] chi2​(double[][][] M,
                              double[][][] Exp)
        Chi^2 - Chi-squared test. If they are correlated, this means unconditional dependence!
        Parameters:
        M - measured joint P(Y_1,Y_2)
        Exp - expect joint P(Y_1)P(Y_2) given null hypothesis
        Returns:
        The chi-square statistic for labels j and k in Y; normalized by critical value.

      • margDepMatrix

        public static double[][] margDepMatrix​(weka.core.Instances D,
                                       String op)
        MargDepMatrix - Get an Unconditional Depndency Matrix.
        Parameters:
        D - dataset
        op - how we will measure the dependency
        Returns:
        a L*L matrix representing Unconditional Depndence.

      • I

        public static double[][] I​(int[][] C,
                           int N)
        I - Get a Mutual Information Matrix.

      • H

        public static double[][] H​(weka.core.Instances D)
        H - Get a Conditional Entropy Matrix.

      • F

        public static double[][] F​(weka.core.Instances D)
        F - Relative frequency matrix (between p(j),p(k) and p(j,k)) in dataset D.

      • condDepMatrix

        public static double[][] condDepMatrix​(weka.core.Instances D,
                                       Result result)
        CondDepMatrix - Get a Conditional Dependency Matrix. Based on Zhang's 'LEAD' approach, where
        the probability of labels j and k both getting errors on the same instance is error(j)*error(k) if the actual co-occurence is otherwise.
        Parameters:
        D - dataset
        Returns:
        a L*L matrix of Unconditional Depndence.

      • LEAD2

        public static double[][] LEAD2​(weka.core.Instances D,
                               Result result)
        LEAD. Do the chi-squared LEAD test on all labels in D. We would expect the 3 kinds of error to be uncorrelacted. However, if they are significantly correlated, this means that there is conditional dependence!

      • LEAD

        public static double[][] LEAD​(weka.core.Instances D,
                              Result R,
                              String MDType)
        LEAD - Performs LEAD on dataset 'D', with corresponding gresult 'R', and dependency measurement type 'MDType'.

      • LEAD

        public static double[][] LEAD​(weka.core.Instances D,
                              Result result)

      • LEAD

        public static double[][] LEAD​(weka.core.Instances D,
                              weka.classifiers.Classifier h,
                              Random r)
                       throws Exception
        LEAD - Performs LEAD on dataset 'D', using BR with base classifier 'h', under random seed 'r'.
        WARNING: changing this method will affect the perfomance of e.g., BCC -- on the other hand the original BCC paper did not use LEAD, so don't worry.
        Throws:
        Exception

      • LEAD

        public static double[][] LEAD​(weka.core.Instances D,
                              weka.classifiers.Classifier h,
                              Random r,
                              String MDType)
                       throws Exception
        Throws:
        Exception
